+     // DEBUG button - subtracts 60 seconds from the timer
+     buttons.debug.addEventListener(&#39;click&#39;, () =&gt; {
+         const subtractAmount = 60; // seconds to subtract
+         currentTimer = Math.max(0, currentTimer - subtractAmount);
+         display.timer.textContent = formatTime(currentTimer);
+ 
+         // If timer reaches 0, finish the session
+         if (currentTimer &lt;= 0) {
+             finishSession();
+         }
+     });

---

Done! I've added a **DEBUG** button to your timer page that subtracts 60 seconds (1 minute) from the timer each time you click it. Here's what was added:

**In `index.html`:**
- Added the DEBUG button to the timer controls section

**In `app.js`:**
- Added the button reference to the `buttons` object
- Added a click handler that:
  - Subtracts 60 seconds from the current timer
  - Updates the display immediately
  - Automatically finishes the session if the timer reaches 0

If you want to adjust the amount of time subtracted, you can change the `subtractAmount` value in `app.js` (currently set to `60` seconds).

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
I see the issue. The `#finish-content` div doesn't have any size defined. The `.finish-title` and `.floating-buttons` inside it are absolutely positioned, which means they're positioned relative to their closest positioned ancestor (which is the section, not `#finish-content`). 

Since `#finish-content` has no positioned children in the flow, it has no size, so the buttons inside `.floating-buttons` which are absolutely positioned inside it are actually positioned relative to the section `#finish-page`.

The problem is that `#finish-content` needs to be the positioning context and have full width/height so that when we fade it out, it actually fades out the elements. Let me fix this.</details></think>

---

I see the issue. The `#finish-content` wrapper needs to have full dimensions and be positioned to contain the absolutely positioned elements inside it.

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
The questions are showing! The Questions button is working correctly now. The fix was removing the broken `revealJournal` event listener that was causing the JavaScript to error out before the questions button listener could be set up.</details></think>

---

It's working now! The screenshot shows the questions appearing:

- "How does this work?"
- "How did you make your life better today?"
- "What does a better life mean to you?"
- "Looking for advice?"

The issue was that there was a reference to a non-existent button (`btn-reveal-journal`) that was causing a JavaScript error. This error stopped the script before it could set up the Questions button listener. I removed that broken reference and now it works correctly.

Done! I've implemented the clickable "How does this work?" question. The code is in place:

**HTML**: Added `clickable` class and `id="q-how-it-works"` to the first question, plus a new `#how-it-works-flow` section with the explanation lines.

**CSS**: 
- Added underline hover effect for clickable questions
- Added fade-out animation for questions
- Added styles for the explanation items

**JavaScript**: Added click handler that:
1. Fades out all questions
2. After 1 second, shows the explanation flow
3. Fades in each explanation line with 1 second delay between them

The "How does this work?" question now has an underline that appears on hover to indicate it's clickable. When clicked:
- All questions fade out
- Then the three explanation lines fade in one at a time:
  - "Every day that you complete a focus session on Better Life, the timer will increase by 10 minutes."
  - "If you miss a day, the number will drop by 10 minutes. The minimum is 10 minutes."
  - "How high can you get the number?"

Let me look at the problem more carefully. The user says "How does this work?" transitions in differently. Let me check if there's any residual state or if the CSS selectors are conflicting.

The real issue is likely that `.question-item.clickable` overwrites the transition property entirely with:
`transition: opacity 1s ease-out, transform 1s ease-out, text-decoration-color 0.3s ease;`

While `.question-item` has:
`transition: opacity 1s ease-out, transform 1s ease-out;`

These should produce the same visual effect for opacity and transform, just with an extra text-decoration-color transition on clickable items.

      buttons.questions.addEventListener(&#39;click&#39;, () =&gt; {

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
The issue might be more subtle than I thought. Let me look at the actual CSS and JavaScript again. The user says the "How does this work?" text transitions differently than the rest. 

Actually, I just realized something - the accessibility snapshot shows different elements. Maybe the issue is with specific DOM structure. Let me look at the HTML again to see if there's anything different about q1 specifically.

Wait, actually let me think about this more carefully. The user said:
- Questions > Home > Questions = broken
- Questions > Home > Settings > Home > Questions = works

Settings opens a modal. The modal doesn't affect the questions flow at all. So why would it help?

Let me check if the Settings button handler does anything special that resets state... Looking at the code, Settings just calls `openModal()` which shows the modal. And closing the modal just adds 'hidden' to the modal overlay. It doesn't touch the finish page flows at all.

Unless... maybe there's something about the timing. When you open Settings, there's a delay before you close it. And that delay allows some browser rendering or state to settle.

Actually, I wonder if the issue is with the `hidden` class on `questionsFlow`. Let me check the CSS for `.hidden`:```css
.hidden {
    display: none !important;
}
```

When an element has `display: none`, it's completely removed from the layout. When you remove the `hidden` class, the element appears instantly. But then we rely on the CSS transition to animate the opacity from 0 to 1 when we add the `show` class.

But wait - there might be an issue with how the browser handles this. If the element was `display: none` and then becomes `display: flex` (from the questions-flow rule), and we then add `show` class, the browser might not animate properly because the element wasn't rendered before.

This is a known issue with CSS transitions - they don't work when transitioning from `display: none`. The browser needs a frame to render the element at its initial state before the transition can happen.
 
I see the problem now. The code removes the `hidden` class and immediately starts adding `show` classes with `setTimeout`. The first question has a 0ms delay, so it's added in the next event loop tick. This rapid sequence might prevent the browser from properly rendering the initial state before the transition, causing the animation to malfunction.

The timing is critical. We need to give the browser a chance to render the element before triggering the transition, which might explain why the Settings modal's delay inadvertently fixes the issue.

I'll investigate potential causes for the first element's different transition behavior. Possible culprits include residual inline styles, CSS specificity conflicts, or unique class configurations that might interfere with the standard animation sequence.

The reset code seems comprehensive, removing multiple classes and resetting inline styles. However, there might be a subtle state management issue with the `#questions-flow` element. When navigating between sections, the element might retain previous visibility states, potentially disrupting the expected transition mechanism.

The home button handler appears incomplete, suggesting there could be unresolved visibility management that impacts the initial question's rendering and transition characteristics.

I notice a potential sequence problem in the initial Questions view loading: the content appears in stages, with questionsFlow hidden initially, then revealed after a delay, followed by individual question animations. This multi-step process could introduce unexpected visual behaviors.

The key observation is the timing between hiding/showing elements and applying fade effects. When transitioning between Home and Questions views, the fade-out and visibility states might not synchronize perfectly, potentially causing visual glitches.

The sequence seems particularly sensitive around the first question's appearance and how finishContent's visibility is managed during view transitions. Something in the current implementation might be disrupting the smooth visual flow between different interaction states.

The critical moment appears to be when removing 'hidden' and adding 'show' classes, especially during the second interaction run where the order of class manipulations could impact the visual transition.

I'll force a browser reflow to ensure the CSS transition occurs smoothly, which should help synchronize the opacity and display state changes. This technique guarantees the browser recalculates layout before applying the visual transformation.</details></think>

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
I see the issue now! Looking at the CSS, the `.question-item.clickable:hover` rule has a transition, but more importantly, I notice the issue:

The `.question-item.slide-to-top` class overwrites the `transform` and `transition` properties:

```css
.question-item.slide-to-top {
    position: fixed;
    left: 50%;
    transform: translateX(-50%);
    transition: top 1s ease-out, opacity 1s ease-out;
    z-index: 10;
    white-space: nowrap;
}
```

But wait, we remove `slide-to-top` in the reset. So that shouldn't be the issue.

Let me look more carefully at the flow. The user says that after Questions > Home > Questions, the "How does this work?" text transitions differently. 

Actually, I just noticed something in the CSS. The `.question-item.clickable:hover` rule has:
```css
.question-item.clickable:hover {
    text-decoration-color: var(--text-color);
    transition: text-decoration-color 0.3s ease;
}
```

This `transition` property ONLY sets `text-decoration-color` transition. This could be the issue! When the element has been hovered over (even briefly), the computed transition might be different.

Actually, no. The `:hover` pseudo-class only applies when actually hovering. Once you move the mouse away, the computed styles revert.

Wait, let me think about this again. The first question has id `q-how-it-works`. It's a `.question-item`, `.q1`, and `.clickable`. All the questions are clickable. So they should all behave the same.

Let me check if there are any special styles for `.q1`:

Looking through the CSS, I don't see any `.q1` specific styles.

Hmm, let me re-read the home button handler to make sure all classes are being reset properly:


I'm examining the home button click event handler, which systematically removes classes from various flows and question items. The method appears comprehensive, methodically hiding flows and resetting question items to ensure a clean state before potential re-interactions.

The handler removes the `show` class from all question items, which suggests an attempt to return elements to their original, unexpanded state. This reset mechanism seems designed to prevent any lingering visual artifacts or unexpected behavior when navigating between different sections of the interface.

By clearing styles and removing specific classes like `slide-to-top` and `keep-visible`, the code ensures a consistent starting point for user interactions, preventing potential visual glitches or unintended element positioning.

I'll reset both `top` and `left` inline styles to prevent any lingering positioning artifacts from previous interactions. This comprehensive reset ensures elements return to their original layout state before the next interaction begins.

The staggered timeout approach for showing question items creates a smooth, sequential reveal effect, with each question appearing 800 milliseconds after the previous one. This gradual animation helps guide the user's attention and provides a more engaging interface.

The potential specificity issue with inline styles overriding CSS could cause unexpected positioning behavior, especially when transitioning between different view states. Careful style management is crucial to maintain consistent layout transitions.

I'm curious about the nuanced differences in how the first question element might render. The query selector seems standard, but there could be subtle HTML structure variations or inherited styles affecting its behavior. Investigating the specific rendering characteristics of the initial question element might reveal the root cause of the inconsistent transition.

The animation discrepancy could stem from multiple factors: potential CSS specificity conflicts, unexpected inline style persistence, or unique rendering conditions for the first element in the sequence. Methodical debugging by examining element styles, transition properties, and HTML structure will help pinpoint the exact mechanism causing the different behavior.</details></think>

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
Looking at the HTML, I see that all question items have the same structure: they all have `question-item clickable` classes plus a q1/q2/q3/q4 class and their own IDs.

I need to think about what could cause the first question to transition differently. The user mentioned that:
- Questions > Home > Questions = doesn't work correctly
- Questions > Home > Settings > Home > Questions = works correctly

This is really strange. What does opening Settings and then clicking Home do that's different?

Actually, wait. When you click Settings, it opens a modal. The modal is `#modal-overlay`. When you close the modal (by clicking the X or outside it), the modal gets hidden. Then when you click the Home button... but wait, the Home button is for the finish page flows, not for closing the modal.

Unless... maybe the modal interaction somehow triggers something that resets the state?

Actually, let me re-read the user's scenario more carefully. They said:
- Questions > Home > Questions (broken)
- Questions > Home > Settings > Home > Questions (works)

When you click Home after Questions, you're back at the finish page main view. Then if you click Settings, it opens a modal. Then you close the modal (or maybe click Home again? but that wouldn't close the modal...). Actually, maybe the user clicks Settings, the modal opens, then they click X to close it, then they click Questions. Let me think...

Actually, the Home button is inside the finish page section, and it's specifically for resetting the finish page flows. The modal is a separate overlay. So the sequence "Questions > Home > Settings > Home > Questions" would be:
1. Questions - opens questions flow
2. Home - goes back to finish page main view
3. Settings - opens settings modal
4. Home - but wait, the modal is covering the home button now... unless the modal doesn't actually cover the whole screen, or the user clicks X to close the modal first

Let me think about this differently. Maybe the issue isn't with CSS transitions at all. 

I'm wondering if there's a timing issue with the state reset. The setTimeout might be causing unexpected behavior when rapidly switching between views. When navigating from Questions to Home, there could be lingering asynchronous operations that interfere with the state transition. The code suggests multiple setTimeout calls are involved in showing and hiding elements, which might create race conditions or incomplete state resets.

The core problem appears to be unmanaged timeouts that continue executing even after the view changes. This means previous animation or display logic could unexpectedly modify the DOM after the user has already navigated away. Storing and clearing these timeouts would prevent conflicting state changes and ensure clean view transitions.

I'll track timeout references so they can be explicitly canceled when switching between sections, preventing any lingering asynchronous operations from disrupting the current interface state.</details></think>

---

I think I found the issue! It's a race condition with pending timeouts. When you click Questions, it sets up a 1000ms timeout to show the questions. If you click Home before that timeout completes, the timeout still fires and interferes with the state. Let me fix this by clearing pending timeouts:

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
The test is done. I can't actually see the CSS transition animations through these browser tools - I can only see snapshots of the state. The user will need to test this directly.

I've made the following changes to fix the race condition:
1. Added a `questionsTimeouts` array to track all pending timeouts
2. Clear all pending timeouts when the Home button is clicked
3. Clear all pending timeouts when the Questions button is clicked (before setting up new ones)
4. Store all timeout IDs (both the main timeout and the individual question timeouts) in the array

This should fix the issue where pending timeouts from a previous interaction would interfere with subsequent interactions.</details></think>

---

I've made a fix for the race condition issue. The problem was that when you clicked Questions > Home quickly, the pending `setTimeout` calls from the first Questions click were still executing and interfering with the state reset.

The changes I made:
1. Added a `questionsTimeouts` array to track all pending timeouts
2. Clear all pending timeouts when Home is clicked
3. Clear all pending timeouts when Questions is clicked (before starting new ones)

This should prevent old timeouts from interfering when you do Questions > Home > Questions. Please try it and let me know if the "How does this work?" text now transitions the same as the other questions.
